Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Completely eliminate package title from the nuget.org UI" (#7149) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This was made less prominent in the nuget.org UI during the UI redesign. I think it's time to remove it so that we can align with the official VS experience. The VS client has had title hidden for 2 major releases now (i.e. multiple years).

This inconsistency is confusing to users (as seen on at least one VS feedback item).

Current package details page:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/57414615-b87d2180-71ad-11e9-819a-6893a48e119c.png)

Current search results:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/57414632-c92d9780-71ad-11e9-967b-a334c6f85562.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix for the package corruption when license file is extracted by Gallery" (#7148) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses #7147.

The issue was that the `_coreLicenseFileService.ExtractAndSaveLicenseFileAsync` call in `PackageUploadService` left the package stream with `Position` pointing to the middle of the stream, so `_packageFileService.SavePackageFileAsync` saved the package starting from that position.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Gallery corrupts packages in local file system when they contain license files" (#7147) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: If gallery is set up to store packages in local file system it corrupts packages that contain license files in them.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add pending migration test" (#7143) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This adds a unit test that fails if there are any pending changes in the entity model. It asserts that if someone was to run `Add-Migration`, an empty migration would be added (indicating the latest migration matches the entity model).

Found with https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7140.
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4934.

2. Make the Search http client timeout configurable in web.config.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Create NuGet package group for VS installer" (#8033) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet has two installable packages in Visual Studio. `Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.BuildTools` and `Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.Core`. The `NuGet.BuildTools` pacakge is intended to be installed with the Visual Studio Build Tools SKU (no UI, used on CI build machines), while the `NuGet.Core` package is intended to be installed with the Visual Studio IDE. The `NuGet.Core` VS package contains all the same dlls that the `NuGet.BuildTools` VS package contains, plus everything else needed for VS integration.

A recent change to the VS installer now prevents multiple packages writing the same file, so will fail if both NuGet VS packages are selected to install. Note: A VS installer component is something that appears in the installer as something with a checkbox that can be selected or unselected. A component has a list of dependencies of packages or package groups. A VS package is what contains dlls to be installed. A package group is also a list of dependencies, like a component, but is not selectable. Dependencies can have when conditions, for example depend on one package for some skus, depend on a different package for different skus.

To fix this, we will create a `Microsoft.VisualStudio.PackageGroup.NuGet` package group that will select the correct package to install depending on which VS SKU is installed. Also modify the existing VS components (things selectable in the installer) to use the package group, rather than the packages directly. This allows customers to install either or both NuGet components without issue.

## Note to Visual Studio extension authors

If you have a dependency on the `Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.BuildTools` or `Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.Core` **package**, you need to change your dependency to `Microsoft.VisualStudio.PackageGroup.NuGet`. However, if your dependency is on the component, it can stay as it is.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Accessibility][Test Failure] Hard to see the cursor in PMC after changing the color theme" (#8119) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet Version: NuGet Client 5.0.0.5371

VS Version: D16.0stg 27930.3001

OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804

2.     Install NuGet Client: \\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\dev\5.0.0.5371\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix

 

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS (default color theme is "Blue") and create a C# Class Library (.NET Framework).

2. Open “Package Manager Console” and “Output” window.

3. Click “Tools->Options->Environment”.

4. Select a different color (e.g. Dark) in the “Color theme” drop-down list.

5. Check the cursor in PMC.

 

Expected:

The cursor is easy to see.

 

Actual:

Hard to see the cursor as attached screenshot. The cursor didn’t change while the theme changed seems the root cause.

 

Note:

1. It didn’t repro before changing the color theme.

2. The cursor will come back after restarting VS.

3. It repro on D16.0stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5278) and D15.9stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5348).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Accessibility][Test Failure] Navigation by “Tab” doesn’t work in PMC window" (#8118) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet Version: NuGet Client 5.0.0.5371

VS Version: D16.0stg 27930.3001

OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804

 

Installation steps:

2.     Install NuGet Client: \\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\dev\5.0.0.5371\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix

 

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS and create a C# Class Library (.NET Framework).

2. Navigate to the menu Tools->NuGet Package Manager->Package Manager Console to open the PMC.

3. Tab through the PMC window.

 

Expected:

Navigation by “Tab” works well.

 

Actual:

Navigation by “Tab” doesn’t work in PMC window as attached screenshot (no rectangle show when hitting ‘Tab’).

 

Note:

1. It doesn’t repro on PM UI.

2. It repro on D16.0stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5278) and D15.9stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5348).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Test Failure] The ‘ProjectName’ column lost in PMC after resetting window layout" (#8117) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
[658342](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/658342)

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS and create a C# Blank App (Universal Windows).

2. Open “Package Manager Console”.

3. Drag the PMC window splitter to right.

4. Type ‘Get-Package -Updates’ in PMC.

5. Click “window->Reset Window Layouts”.

6. Open “Package Manager Console” and type ‘Get-Package -Updates’ in PMC again.

7. Drag the PMC window splitter to right and observe the package information.

Expected:

The ‘ProjectName’ column should be displayed in step 7 such as step 4.

Actual:

The ‘ProjectName’ column lost in step 7 as attachment picture. 

Notes:

1. The issue repro on D16.0stg 28002.3000 (default NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-preview3/4.8.0.5278).

2. The issue repro on D15.8 28002.3000 + NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM\4.8.0.5374.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.exe pack causing a file probe of everything in in the file src directory" (#8115) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet probes all files in a referenced files directory. This causes many violations in our cache-able build system.

In the nuspec we will have something

  <files>
    <file src="myDirectory$\foo.lib" target="content\$SdkLibPathDest$" />
  </files>

**Actual**: Every file in myDirectory then gets accessed.
**Expected:** Only foo.lib gets accessed.


NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 5.0.0.5923:

dotnet.exe --version: NA

VS version: NA

OS version: win10 v.1809 OS Build 17763.437

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

The repo steps are to run “nuget pack” on a .nuspec file that points to a single file in a directory that has other files in it. Aka, the nuspec contains d:\foo\1.txt, and the directory d:\foo contains 1.txt and 2.txt. The nuget pack command will probe for d:\foo\1.txt and d:\foo\2.txt even though only d:\foo.1.txt was specified in the nuspec.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet assembly versions should be consistent" (#8113) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
After adjusting the Visual Studio installation path (on the first line below) as necessary, execute the following PowerShell script:
```PowerShell
$directory = [System.IO.DirectoryInfo]::new('C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\NuGet')

$files = $directory.GetFiles('NuGet.*.dll')

$assemblyVersionsMap = [System.Collections.Generic.SortedDictionary[string, [System.Collections.Hashtable]]]::new()

ForEach ($file In $files)
{
    $assembly = [System.Reflection.Assembly]::LoadFile($file.FullName)
    $assemblyName = [System.Reflection.AssemblyName]::new($assembly.FullName)
    $fileVersionInfo = [System.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo]::GetVersionInfo($file.FullName)
    $versions = @{
        AssemblyVersion = $assemblyName.Version
        FileVersion = $fileVersionInfo.FileVersion
        ProductVersion = $fileVersionInfo.ProductVersion
    }

    $assemblyVersionsMap.Add($assemblyName.Name, $versions)
}

$assemblyVersionsMap | Format-Table `
    @{ Label = 'Assembly';         Expression = 'Key' }, `
    @{ Label = 'Assembly Version'; Expression = { $_.Value.AssemblyVersion } }, `
    @{ Label = 'File Version';     Expression = { $_.Value.FileVersion } }, `
    @{ Label = 'Product Version';  Expression = { $_.Value.ProductVersion } }
```
Sample output:

Assembly | Assembly Version | File Version | Product Version
--- | --- | --- | ---

NuGet.Common | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.Configuration | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.Console | **5.0.0.5917** | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.Credentials | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.DependencyResolver.Core | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.Frameworks | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68

NuGet.PackageManagement.UI | **5.0.0.5917** | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio | **5.0.0.5917** | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.Packaging | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.ProjectModel | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68

NuGet.Tools | **5.0.0.5917** | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68

NuGet.VisualStudio.Implementation | 5.0.0.6 | 5.0.0.5917 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68
NuGet.VisualStudio.Interop | 1.0.0.0 | 1.0.0.0 | 5.0.0-rtm.5917+f2696527402305a7d7e51ca2aab1dc1c704d7c68


NuGet.VisualStudio.Interop.dll's assembly version should always be 1.0.0.0; however, I'm not aware of any good reason why all other assemblies don't have the same assembly version of 5.0.0.6.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "locals command description in nuget.exe and dotnet.exe differ" (#8112) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used NuGet.exe | dotnet.exe

NuGet.exe 4.9.4.5839
dotnet.exe: .NET Core SDK (3.0.100-preview4-011223)

Worked before? No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Run `nuget.exe`

```powershell
> nuget.exe
NuGet Version: 4.9.4.5839
usage: NuGet <command> [args] [options]
Type 'NuGet help <command>' for help on a specific command.

Available commands:

 add               Adds the given package to a hierarchical source. http sources are not supported. For more info, goto https://docs.nuget.org/consume/command-line-reference#add-command.

 config            Gets or sets NuGet config values.

 delete            Deletes a package from the server.

 help (?)          Displays general help information and help information about other commands.

 init              Adds all the packages from the <srcPackageSourcePath> to the hierarchical <destPackageSourcePath>. http feeds are not supported. For more info, goto https://docs.nuget.org/consume/command-line-reference#init-command.

 install           Installs a package using the specified sources. If no sources are specified, all sources defined in the NuGet configuration file are used. If the configuration file specifies no sources, uses the default NuGet feed.

 list              Displays a list of packages from a given source. If no sources are specified, all sources defined in %AppData%\NuGet\NuGet.config are used. If NuGet.config specifies no sources, uses the default NuGet feed.

 locals            Clears or lists local NuGet resources such as http requests cache, temp cache or machine-wide global packages folder.

 pack              Creates a NuGet package based on the specified nuspec or project file.

 push              Pushes a package to the server and publishes it.
                   NuGet's default configuration is obtained by loading %AppData%\NuGet\NuGet.config, then loading any nuget.config or .nuget\nuget.config starting from root of drive and ending in current directory.

 restore           Restores NuGet packages.

 setApiKey         Saves an API key for a given server URL. When no URL is provided API key is saved for the NuGet gallery.

 sign              Signs a NuGet package with the specified certificate.

 sources           Provides the ability to manage list of sources located in %AppData%\NuGet\NuGet.config

 spec              Generates a nuspec for a new package. If this command is run in the same folder as a project file (.csproj, .vbproj, .fsproj), it will create a tokenized nuspec file.

 trusted-signers   Provides the ability to manage the list of trusted signers.

 update            Update packages to latest available versions. This command also updates NuGet.exe itself.

 verify            Verifies a signed NuGet package.

For more information, visit http://docs.nuget.org/docs/reference/command-line-reference
```

2. Run `dotnet.exe nuget`

```powershell
> dotnet nuget
NuGet Command Line 5.1.0.0

Usage: dotnet nuget [options] [command]

Options:
  -h|--help                   Show help information
  --version                   Show version information
  -v|--verbosity <verbosity>  The verbosity of logging to use. Allowed values: Debug, Verbose, Information, Minimal, Warning, Error.

Commands:
  delete  Deletes a package from the server.
  locals  Clears or lists local NuGet resources such as http requests cache, packages folder, plugin operations cache  or machine-wide global packages folder.
  push    Pushes a package to the server and publishes it.

Use "dotnet nuget [command] --help" for more information about a command.
```

### Expected

Both command descriptions should be the same, since both have the same source code.

### Actual

Commands descriptions differ:

nuget.exe
```
Clears or lists local NuGet resources such as http requests cache, temp cache or machine-wide global packages folder.
```

dotnet.exe:
```
Clears or lists local NuGet resources such as http requests cache, packages folder, plugin operations cache  or machine-wide global packages folder.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ".NET Core global tool package signature failure: local file header is corrupt" (#8111) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.9.2

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.2.103

VS version (if appropriate): 15.9.20+g88f5fadfbe

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Win 10

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Not with this project, but worked with other .NET Core global tools we've created with similar configurations.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Using the latest version of [SignService](https://github.com/dotnet/SignService) and a valid code signing certificate (DigiCert is our root CA in this case), build and sign the following .NET Core global tool: https://github.com/petabridge/Incrementalist - `Incrementalist.Cmd` is the .NET Core global tool produced in this case.

2. Once you have a SignService setup and have populated your credentials inside [appsettings.json](https://github.com/petabridge/Incrementalist/blob/dev/appsettings.json), run the following build command: `./build.cmd nuget SignClientUser={user} SignClientSecret={secret}`

3. Run `nuget verify Incrementalist.Cmd.nupkg -All -verbosity detailed`

You'll receive the following error message:

```
'D:\Downloads\Incrementalist.Cmd.0.1.0 (1).nupkg' is not a valid package file.
A local file header is corrupt.
System.IO.InvalidDataException: A local file header is corrupt.
   at System.IO.Compression.ZipArchiveEntry.ThrowIfNotOpenable(Boolean needToUncompress, Boolean needToLoadIntoMemory)
   at System.IO.Compression.ZipArchiveEntry.OpenInReadMode(Boolean checkOpenable)
   at NuGet.Packaging.PackageArchiveReader.GetStream(String path)
   at NuGet.Packaging.PackageReaderBase.get_NuspecReader()
   at NuGet.Packaging.PackageReaderBase.GetIdentity()
   at NuGet.Commands.VerifyCommandRunner.<VerifySignatureForPackageAsync>d__4.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.VerifyCommandRunner.<ExecuteCommandAsync>d__3.MoveNext()
```

It's not clear why this happening - we have other .NET Core tools that we're able to sign no problem. One thing I do notice looking inside the guts of the project after we've signed it with SignService: there's no `.signature` file in the contents of the .nupkg afterwards, whereas there are in our other signed .NET Core global tools projects.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add MSBuild /t:pack / restore tests. " (#8110) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
For some scenarios (see https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/2850), dotnet restore and nuget.exe restore tests are insufficient. 
nuget.exe doesn't play well post-pre restore msbuild tasks. 
dotnet.exe cannot build/restore every project type in the world (for obvious reasons). 

An example bootstrap script I use locally. 

```powershell
Function Invoke-NuGetCustom()
{
	$packDllPath = Join-Path $nugetClientRoot "artifacts\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\16.0\bin\Debug\net472\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.dll"
	$packTargetsPath = Join-Path $nugetClientRoot "src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets"
	
	$restoreDllPath = Join-Path $nugetClientRoot "artifacts\NuGet.Build.Tasks\16.0\bin\Debug\net472\NuGet.Build.Tasks.dll"
	$nugetRestoreTargetsPath = Join-Path $nugetClientRoot "src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.Build.Tasks\NuGet.targets"

	Write-Host "msbuild /p:NuGetRestoreTargets=$nugetRestoreTargetsPath /p:RestoreTaskAssemblyFile=$restoreDllPath /p:NuGetBuildTasksPackTargets=$packTargetsPath /p:ImportNuGetBuildTasksPackTargetsFromSdk="true" /p:NuGetPackTaskAssemblyFile=$packDllPath $($args[0..$args.Count])" 
	& msbuild /p:NuGetRestoreTargets=$nugetRestoreTargetsPath /p:RestoreTaskAssemblyFile=$restoreDllPath /p:NuGetBuildTasksPackTargets=$packTargetsPath /p:ImportNuGetBuildTasksPackTargetsFromSdk="true" /p:NuGetPackTaskAssemblyFile=$packDllPath $args[0..$args.Count]
}
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove Newtonsoft.Json reference from NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio" (#8109) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While testing 5.1 insertion in VS, NuGet package manager UI failed due to being unable to load Newtonsoft.Json version 10.

For now we'll remove the dependency, and try to fix the issue later with #8108

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
